entry.title: Hundreds of protesters injured as anger simmers in Beirut

media:group.media:title: Hundreds of protesters injured as anger simmers in Beirut
media:group.media:description:
Outrage over Tuesday's explosion in Lebanon's capital has spilled onto its streets as thousands of people rallied - furious at the government. The protests descended into hours of street battles between demonstrators and security forces. One policeman is dead, and hundreds of people have been injured.
Al Jazeera's Zeina Khodr reports from Beirut, Lebanon.

entry.title: Air India Express crash: Investigators find black box data

media:group.media:title: Air India Express crash: Investigators find black box data
media:group.media:description:
Flight data recorders have been recovered from the wreckage of a Boeing 737 which crash-landed in India on Friday. Both pilots are among 18 dead in the accident in Kozhikode in Kerala state. Around 150 passengers and crew were injured as the workers' repatriation flight from Dubai plunged off the end of the runway. Al Jazeera’s Sara Khairat reports.

entry.title: Beijing's top office in Hong Kong slams 'ridiculous' US sanctions

media:group.media:title: Beijing's top office in Hong Kong slams 'ridiculous' US sanctions
media:group.media:description:
Hong Kong has slammed the US for imposing sanctions on its leaders, calling the decision "despicable and barbarous". Chief executive Carrie Lam and the current and former police chiefs are among 11 officials whose US assets will be frozen. Al Jazeera’s Sarah Clarke reports from Hong Kong.

entry.title: Mauritius declares emergency over oil spill from grounded ship

media:group.media:title: Mauritius declares emergency over oil spill from grounded ship
media:group.media:description:
Mauritius has declared a state of environmental emergency after a grounded Japanese-owned ship began spilling tonnes of oil. France is to send help from Reunion, its neighbouring territory, and a volunteer clean-up operation is already under way. Al Jazeera’s Emily Siu reports.

entry.title: Belarus: Lukashenko looks for sixth victory in tough contest

media:group.media:title: Belarus: Lukashenko looks for sixth victory in tough contest
media:group.media:description:
Three Russian opposition activists have been detained as they travelled to Belarus to observe a tense presidential election. President Alexander Lukashenko is facing the strongest opposition yet to his leadership. He is expected to declare victory after Sunday’s elections, his sixth in 25 years. But the opposition says it will fight the election results in court. Al Jazeera’s Step Vaessen reports from Minsk.

entry.title: Papua New Guinea sounds alarm with WHO as coronavirus cases surge

media:group.media:title: Papua New Guinea sounds alarm with WHO as coronavirus cases surge
media:group.media:description:
COVID-19 has left Pacific Island nations relatively untouched. But an increase in infections in Papua New Guinea is straining the already fragile healthcare system. Al Jazeera's Nicola Gage reports.

entry.title: More than a dozen killed in 'devastating' India plane crash

media:group.media:title: More than a dozen killed in 'devastating' India plane crash
media:group.media:description:
At least 18 people have been killed in a plane crash in India and more than 100 injured. The aircraft slid off the runway as it was coming into land at Kozhikode airport in the southern state of Kerala, in heavy monsoon rain. Al Jazeera's Emma Hayward reports.

entry.title: Rajapaksa brothers win by landslide in Sri Lanka's election

media:group.media:title: Rajapaksa brothers win by landslide in Sri Lanka's election
media:group.media:description:
The Rajapaksa brothers have cemented their hold on power in Sri Lanka with a dominating win in the country's parliamentary elections. Mahinda Rajapaksa will remain prime minister – and his brother, Gotabaya, the president. And, as Al Jazeera's Minelle Fernandez reports from Colombo, they now plan to change the Sri Lankan constitution.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #SriLanka #Rajapaksa

entry.title: Beirut port explosion: Officials detained as probe promised

media:group.media:title: Beirut port explosion: Officials detained as probe promised
media:group.media:description:
An international donor conference to collect aid for Lebanon is scheduled for Sunday. The country is in desperate need of help after an explosion at the port in Beirut on Tuesday. President Michel Aoun has promised an investigation into whether the blast in Beirut was caused by negligence, an accident or even a rocket or bomb. But the government is facing widespread anger over accusations of mismanagement and corruption. At least 157 people have been confirmed dead and more than 6,000 injured. Al Jazeera's Zeina Khodr has this report from Beirut.

entry.title: Is the US-Saudi Arabia relationship falling apart? | Inside Story

media:group.media:title: Is the US-Saudi Arabia relationship falling apart? | Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
Former Saudi intelligence agent Saad Al Jabri is suing the Saudi Crown Prince in the US, alleging Mohammed Bin Salman sent the 'hit squad' that murdered Jamal Khashoggi to kill him in Canada. In a rare rebuke, the State Department praised Jabri and demanded answers about the safety of his children. Will President Donald Trump, a staunch supporter for Bin Salman, be forced to take action?
Presenter: Adrian Finighan
Guests:
Khalil Jahshan - Executive Director, Arab Center Washington DC
Mahjoob Zweiri - Director, Gulf Studies Center, Qatar University
Rami Khouri - Senior Fellow, Issam Fares Institute, American University of Beirut
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: Colombians revel, protest over order to detain ex-President Uribe

media:group.media:title: Colombians revel, protest over order to detain ex-President Uribe
media:group.media:description:
Protests have been held across Colombia after the Supreme Court put former President Alvaro Uribe under house arrest. His supporters have been rallying in their cars across the country's major cities with the detention deepening political divisions. Al Jazeera's Alessandro Rampietti reports from the capital, Bogota.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #Uribe #Colombia

media:group.media:title: Venezuela: Breaking lockdown rules punished
media:group.media:description:
Venezuela's government is being accused of taking punishing measures against people who break quarantine rules imposed to curb the spread of COVID-19. But the prolonged lockdown has severely affected the economy and many simply cannot afford to stay at home any more. Al Jazeera's Laura Burdon-Manley reports.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #Venezuela #Maduro

entry.title: Jobless Kenyans question misuse of foreign aid

media:group.media:title: Jobless Kenyans question misuse of foreign aid
media:group.media:description:
Many Kenyans who lost their jobs because of the coronavirus pandemic accuse the government of misusing foreign aid to help them. Many say they are yet to receive any money. Al Jazeera's Catherine Soi reports from Nairobi, Kenya.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #Kenya #Unemployment

entry.title: UK economy: Bank warns of biggest decline in century

media:group.media:title: UK economy: Bank warns of biggest decline in century
media:group.media:description:
The latest Bank of England forecast says the British economy is facing its biggest annual decline for 100 years. And bankers warn it could take more than a year to get back to pre-lockdown levels, provided there is not a second surge of coronavirus infections. Al Jazeera's Neave Barker reports from London, UK.
